importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of a call from a fake Defence Minister Guido Crosetto voice, which led to a reported scam involving Italian businessmen.
The date on which Defence Minister Guido Crosetto publicly addressed the scam, confirming he had not received a call from his office asking for his mobile number.
The start of a period during which deepfake scams began rising globally, with reports from January to June 2025.
Date when Resemble AI released a report showing a sharp increase in deepfake scams, including the creation of AI-generated child sexual abuse material.
Date when US President Donald Trump signed legislation making it a federal crime to publish AI-generated intimate images of individuals without consent.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which AI voice cloning scams surged globally, particularly in early 2025, and when deepfakes of real people began being used for fraud and abuse.

keyTakeAways: AI-generated voices have become indistinguishable from real human voices in many cases, especially when cloned from real individuals.
A scam involving fake calls from Defence Minister Guido Crosetto targeted several wealthy Italian businessmen, including Giorgio Armani and Patrizio Bertelli.
Only Massimo Moratti, former owner of Inter Milan, made a real financial transfer in response to the scam, which was later frozen by police.

Research from Queen Mary University of London found that 41% of AI-generated voices and 58% of voice clones were mistaken for real human voices, with participants often rating AI voices as more trustworthy.
AI voice cloning can be used for malicious purposes such as identity theft, fraud, and generating fake news or illegal content like AI-generated child sexual abuse material.

The rise in AI-generated deepfakes has led to global policy responses, including US legislation criminalizing the publication of AI-generated intimate images and Australia banning an app used to create such deepfakes.
Despite risks, AI voice technology has positive applications, such as restoring speech for individuals with speech disabilities.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A wave of AI-generated voice scams targeting wealthy Italian businessmen began in early 2025, with fraudsters cloning the voice of Defence Minister Guido Crosetto to request large financial transfers. The scam, which also involved fake calls from a 'General' and requests for personal information, was exposed after Crosetto publicly denied receiving such calls. Research from Queen Mary University of London found that AI-generated voice clones are nearly indistinguishable from real human voices, with participants often rating them as more trustworthy. The global rise in deepfake fraud—over $547 million lost between January and June 2025—has led to urgent policy responses, including US federal laws criminalizing AI-generated intimate imagery and Australia banning apps used to create deepfakes. While AI voice technology offers positive applications such as restoring speech for the disabled, its misuse for identity theft, fraud, and the creation of illegal content, especially child sexual abuse material, poses serious societal risks.
title: AI now sounds more like us – should we be concerned?
